A troubled primary school where teachers are due to walk out on strike has been issued with a formal warning over the way it is being governed. 
Council bosses have issued the notice to governors at Bollin Primary School over unresolved grievances raised by staff. 
Parents and teachers at the school, in Bowdon , say they have become increasingly worried by the way in which a previously " happy, successful school " is now being run. 
Education chiefs at Trafford council say there was "clear evidence" that "numerous" complaints from teachers and parents had not been dealt with by governors. The warning notice, issued on Thursday, February 16, gives the council powers to formally step in if the school does not comply with its requirements. 
Governors have blamed a "backlog of paperwork" for the unresolved grievances at Bollin. Read More Pregnant woman ended up with football-sized cyst after doctors let it keep growing inside her 
Tony Field, chairman of governors at Bollin Primary School, said: "The newly elected governing body of the Bollin Primary School acknowledges that there is a backlog of paperwork which was inherited from the previous governing body. 
"We are working through each individual case and plan to have all outstanding issues resolved as soon as possible." 
The council's intervention comes ahead of six days of strike action planned by teachers at Bollin Primary. The first walkout is planned on Thursday, February 23. 
Union bosses say the dispute centres around workload, "excessive scrutiny" and an "obsession" with data relating to pupil progress. Trafford Council has issued a warning notice to governors at Bollin Primary School. (Photo: Manchester Evening News) 
Parents took their concerns a step further by launching an online petition airing their vote of no confidence in leaders at Bollin. One parent, who has asked not to be identified, said: "We know we are lucky to live in a nice affluent area with a good school. 
"But there has been a growing groundswell of outrage at the way Bollin is being run." 
But headteacher Michelle Brindle has defended her leadership, arguing that the school had a "long line" of exciting things ahead this year. 
She said: "As headteacher, I am one hundred per cent committed to my position, the pupils and the team. I want to work alongside parents and the governors to make the school a happy and inspirational environment for both the children and staff." 
The last time the school was inspected by Ofsted was in 2007 when it was rated as "outstanding". Read More 
It is understood a private firm called ECM Education were drafted in to carry out a "mocksted" inspection in September when Mrs Brindle took up her post. 
Tensions at the school are said to have deepened following the resignation of four governors in December. 
Peter Middleman, regional secretary for the NUT, said: "The dispute at Bollin Primary is regrettable in that it is wholly avoidable. 
"Staff have been raising legitimate concerns since last autumn about workloads, excessive scrutiny and an obsession with the capture and manipulation of data relating to pupil progress which has become a significant impediment to good teaching and learning. 
"In talks with governors at the school, and with the local authority, we were able to make promising early progress but this has regressed since the team of governors has been gradually replaced, some more than once, since December. 
"That lack of continuity in governance has contributed to a deterioration in industrial relations and with no prospect of a resolution of the main issues, members have chosen to exercise their right to strike." Read More
